dt: {bc}to lie immersed in liquid (such as water) {bc}become saturated by or as if by immersion
{bc}to enter or pass through something by or as if by pores or interstices {bc}{sx|permeate||}
{bc}to penetrate or affect the mind or feelings
{bc}to permeate so as to wet, soften, or fill thoroughly
{bc}to place in a surrounding element (such as liquid) to wet or permeate thoroughly
{bc}to extract by or as if by steeping
{bc}to draw or take in by or as if by suction or absorption
{bc}to cause to pay an exorbitant amount

pt: {sc}soak{/sc} {sc}saturate{/sc} {sc}drench{/sc} {sc}steep{/sc} {sc}impregnate{/sc} mean to permeate or be permeated with a liquid. {sc}soak{/sc} implies usually prolonged immersion as for softening or cleansing.
{sc}saturate{/sc} implies a resulting effect of complete absorption until no more liquid can be held.
{sc}drench{/sc} implies a thorough wetting by something that pours down or is poured.
{sc}steep{/sc} suggests either the extraction of an essence (as of tea leaves) by the liquid or the imparting of a quality (such as a color) to the thing immersed.
{sc}impregnate{/sc} implies a thorough interpenetration of one thing by another.

et: Middle English {it}soken{/it}, from Old English {it}socian{/it}; akin to Old English {it}sūcan{/it} to suck
shortdef: to lie immersed in liquid (such as water) : become saturated by or as if by immersion
to enter or pass through something by or as if by pores or interstices : permeate
to penetrate or affect the mind or feelings —usually used with in or into
